sentence: After weeks of deliberation, they finally decided to go ______ with the plan.
explanation: To <go ahead with> means to proceed with something.

sentence: The company had to lay ______ a significant portion of its workforce.
explanation: To <lay off> means to dismiss employees, usually temporarily, due to economic conditions.

sentence: He tried to talk her ______ of resigning, but she was determined.
explanation: To <talk someone out of> something means to persuade them not to do it.

sentence: The new regulations will come ______ effect next month.
explanation: To <come into effect> means to become operative or valid.

sentence: She always stands ______ for what she believes is right.
explanation: To <stand up for> means to defend or support someone or something.

sentence: The project was called ______ at the last minute due to lack of funding.
explanation: To <call off> means to cancel something.

sentence: He managed to get ______ with only a warning despite breaking the rules.
explanation: To <get away with> means to do something wrong or illegal without being punished or caught.

sentence: The new manager is trying to crack ______ on absenteeism.
explanation: To <crack down on> means to become more strict in dealing with something.

sentence: I can't quite put my finger ______ what's wrong with this picture.
explanation: To <put your finger on> something means to identify precisely what is wrong or different.

sentence: They decided to do ______ with the old system and implement a new one.
explanation: To <do away with> means to abolish or get rid of something.

sentence: She always looks ______ to her older sister for advice.
explanation: To <look up to> means to admire and respect someone.

sentence: The company is trying to cut ______ on unnecessary expenses.
explanation: To <cut back on> means to reduce the amount of something.

sentence: He finally came ______ to the idea of moving abroad.
explanation: To <come around to> means to change your opinion or decision because someone has persuaded you.

sentence: The new policy will bring ______ significant changes to the department.
explanation: To <bring about> means to cause something to happen.

sentence: She's always been able to get ______ with people from all walks of life.
explanation: To <get along with> means to have a friendly relationship with someone.

sentence: The police are looking ______ the cause of the fire.
explanation: To <look into> means to investigate something.

sentence: He's been trying to live ______ his reputation as a troublemaker.
explanation: To <live down> means to overcome the shame or embarrassment of a past mistake or reputation.

sentence: The new evidence bears ______ the witness's testimony.
explanation: To <bear out> means to confirm or support the truth of something.

sentence: She always puts her ideas ______ clearly and concisely.
explanation: To <put across> means to communicate an idea or message effectively.

sentence: The company decided to branch ______ into new markets.
explanation: To <branch out> means to expand into new areas of business or activity.

sentence: He's been trying to drum ______ support for his campaign.
explanation: To <drum up> means to try to get support or business.

sentence: The new system will phase ______ the old one over the next year.
explanation: To <phase out> means to gradually stop using something.

sentence: She always manages to pull ______ her presentations with confidence.
explanation: To <pull off> means to succeed in doing something difficult or unexpected.

sentence: The committee decided to press ______ with the investigation despite the difficulties.
explanation: To <press on> means to continue doing something in a determined way.

sentence: He's been trying to sound her ______ about her plans.
explanation: To <sound out> means to try to find out someone's opinions or intentions.

sentence: The new policy will take ______ from next Monday.
explanation: To <take effect> means to become operative.

sentence: She always stands ______ for her friends when they are in trouble.
explanation: To <stand by> means to support someone, especially in a difficult situation.

sentence: The company decided to wind ______ its operations in the country.
explanation: To <wind up> means to close down a business or organization.

sentence: He's been trying to worm his way ______ of his responsibilities.
explanation: To <worm your way out of> something means to avoid doing something you should do.

sentence: The new evidence will throw new light ______ the case.
explanation: To <throw new light on> means to provide new information that helps to explain something.

sentence: She always manages to talk her way ______ of difficult situations.
explanation: To <talk your way out of> something means to escape from a difficult situation by talking.

sentence: The company decided to knuckle ______ and finish the project on time.
explanation: To <knuckle down> means to start working hard, especially when you should have done it earlier.

sentence: He's been trying to patch ______ his relationship with his brother.
explanation: To <patch up> means to repair a relationship or settle a disagreement.

sentence: The new regulations will come ______ force next year.
explanation: To <come into force> means to become law or start to be applied.

sentence: She always manages to get her point ______ effectively.
explanation: To <get your point across> means to make your ideas understood.

sentence: The company decided to hold ______ on making a decision until next week.
explanation: To <hold off> means to delay doing something.

sentence: He's been trying to butter her ______ so she'll agree to his proposal.
explanation: To <butter someone up> means to flatter them in order to get something from them.

sentence: The new policy will be rolled ______ nationwide next month.
explanation: To <roll out> means to officially make a new product or service available.

sentence: She always manages to smooth things ______ when there's a conflict.
explanation: To <smooth over> means to make problems or difficulties seem less serious or important.

sentence: He's been trying to square ______ his actions with his conscience.
explanation: To <square with> means to be consistent with or agree with something.
